title: Anoxic Brain Injury / Neuroprognostication
icd10: I46.2 (Cardiac arrest due to underlying cardiac condition)
I46.8 (Cardiac arrest due to other underlying condition)
G40.901 (Epilepsy with status epilepticus — post-anoxic seizures)
scope: ** Acute management, targeted temperature management (TTM), neuroprognostication, and rehabilitation pathway for anoxic brain injury following cardiac arrest or other causes of global cerebral hypoxia in adults. Covers post-cardiac arrest care bundle (TTM 32-36C for 24h, hemodynamic optimization, seizure management), multimodal neuroprognostication (clinical exam, EEG, SSEP, MRI, biomarkers, CT), confounder identification and elimination, myoclonus classification, and rehabilitation pathway for survivors. Excludes neonatal HIE, pediatric cardiac arrest, primary respiratory arrest without cardiac arrest, focal stroke, and traumatic brain injury.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline; infection screen; thrombocytopenia from ischemia-reperfusion
Electrolytes; renal function (ischemic ATN common); hepatic injury (shock liver); glucose management
Oxygenation; ventilation; acid-base status; lactate clearance
Essential/Core Labs.target: pH 7.35-7.45; PaCO2 35-45; PaO2 >60; lactate trending down

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Tissue perfusion marker; serial clearance predicts survival
Myocardial injury is nearly universal post-arrest; ACS as precipitant; myocardial dysfunction severity
Essential/Core Labs.target: Trend; peak predicts myocardial dysfunction severity

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: DIC screen; consumptive coagulopathy from prolonged arrest
Hyperglycemia worsens neurological outcomes; hypoglycemia mimics encephalopathy
Hypomagnesemia lowers seizure threshold; arrhythmia risk
Potential need for blood products; DIC management
Toxicologic cause of arrest (cocaine, opioids, amphetamines); affects prognostication timeline
Confounding factor for neurological exam; withdrawal risk

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Prognostic biomarker; draw at 24h, 48h, and 72h post-ROSC. NSE >33 ug/L at 48-72h associated with poor outcome (FPR <5% per ERC/ESICM 2021). Must exclude hemolysis (falsely elevates NSE)
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: <33 ug/L at 48-72h suggests potential for recovery; >60 ug/L highly predictive of poor outcome

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Differentiate post-arrest SIRS from infection; guide antibiotic decisions
Adrenal insufficiency from prolonged shock; critical illness-related corticosteroid insufficiency
Post-arrest myocardial dysfunction severity; volume status
Hepatic encephalopathy confounding neurologic exam; shock liver
Monitor during osmotherapy if cerebral edema develops

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Additional prognostic biomarker; less studied than NSE; elevated >0.18 ug/L at 24-48h suggests poor outcome
Emerging biomarker for axonal injury severity; research context
Emerging astrocytic injury biomarker; elevated in severe ABI
Emerging biomarker for axonal injury; correlates with outcome at 24-72h post-arrest
Channelopathy workup if arrest etiology unclear in young patient without structural heart disease
Cyanide, carbon monoxide, organophosphates if environmental exposure suspected
Carbon monoxide poisoning as cause of anoxia; house fire, CO exposure

Essential/First-line.timing: Immediately post-ROSC; rule out primary intracranial event as cause of arrest
Essential/First-line.target: Exclude hemorrhage, stroke, herniation, mass as primary cause. Post-anoxic findings: diffuse sulcal effacement, loss of gray-white differentiation (GWR) — GWR <1.1 at 24-48h predicts poor outcome

Essential/First-line.timing: Immediately post-ROSC; identify STEMI (emergent cath), arrhythmia, QTc, Brugada, channelopathy
Essential/First-line.target: STEMI -> emergent PCI; arrhythmia identification; QTc assessment

Essential/First-line.timing: ETT position; rib fractures from CPR; aspiration; pulmonary edema
Emergent if STEMI; urgent if no obvious non-cardiac etiology and shockable rhythm (VF/VT). AHA/ILCOR: emergent PCI for STEMI; consider early cath for non-STEMI arrests with shockable rhythm
Essential/First-line.target: Identify and treat coronary occlusion as precipitant of arrest
Essential/First-line.contraindications: Active bleeding; known anaphylaxis to contrast

Essential/First-line.timing: Initiate within 12h of ICU admission; detect nonconvulsive seizures (NCSE in 10-30% of comatose post-arrest); monitor for burst-suppression; assess background reactivity for prognostication at >=72h
Essential/First-line.target: Background: continuous vs burst-suppression vs suppression; reactivity to stimuli; seizures/NCSE. Highly malignant patterns (suppression, burst-suppression without reactivity) predict poor outcome

Essential/First-line.timing: Within 24h; assess post-arrest myocardial dysfunction (stunned myocardium); EF for hemodynamic management; identify structural cause (HCM, valvular)
Essential/First-line.target: Post-arrest EF often 25-40% (usually recovers by 72h); wall motion abnormalities; structural abnormality

Extended.timing: Day 2-7 post-ROSC (optimal at day 3-5); critical for neuroprognostication. DWI is most sensitive imaging modality for anoxic injury
Extended.target: Extensive cortical and subcortical restricted diffusion (DWI bright, ADC dark) = poor outcome. Diffuse cortical involvement, basal ganglia, thalamic, brainstem involvement all predict poor outcome. Quantitative ADC values may improve accuracy
Extended.contraindications: Pacemaker (non-MRI-conditional); hemodynamic instability; active TTM devices (MRI-compatible alternatives exist)

Extended.timing: Perform at >=72h post-ROSC after rewarming and sedation washout. Bilateral absence of N20 cortical responses is one of the most reliable poor prognostic indicators (FPR <1%)
Extended.target: Bilateral N20 present = good sign. Bilateral N20 absent = poor prognosis (FPR ~0-1% per AAN). N20 amplitude <0.62 uV also predictive
Extended.contraindications: None absolute; requires cooperative technician and reduced electrical interference

Extended.item: CT head with quantitative GWR measurement
Extended.timing: At 24-48h post-ROSC; measure gray-white matter ratio at basal ganglia level and centrum semiovale
Extended.target: GWR <1.10 at caudate nucleus level at 24-48h predicts poor outcome (FPR <5%). Diffuse sulcal effacement, absent basal cisterns, loss of differentiation

Extended.timing: If available; assess metabolic injury severity
Extended.target: Reduced NAA/Cr ratio; elevated lactate peak = poor prognosis

Extended.timing: After stabilization; assess myocardial injury, cardiomyopathy, fibrosis, ARVC
Extended.target: Structural/ischemic etiology of arrest; myocardial viability

Rare/Specialized.timing: If catheterization deferred or non-STEMI; non-invasive coronary evaluation
After recovery; if arrhythmic etiology suspected and ICD consideration
Rare/Specialized.target: Inducible VT/VF; risk stratification for ICD

Rare/Specialized.timing: Research context; assess global cerebral perfusion
Rare/Specialized.target: Absent cortical perfusion predicts poor outcome

Acute/Emergent.indication: ALL comatose cardiac arrest survivors (GCS motor <6 after ROSC). TTM2 trial: no difference between 33C vs 36C; both superior to fever. AHA/ILCOR 2020: target 32-36C for at least 24h

doseOptions.orderSentence: Targeted Temperature Management (TTM) — cooling to 32-36C 32-36C external/IV

dosing.instructions: Initiate cooling ASAP post-ROSC; use surface (Arctic Sun) or intravascular (Thermogard) cooling; target temperature within 4h; maintain for at least 24h; rewarm at 0.25C/h (avoid >0.5C/h); prevent fever (<37.7C) for at least 72h after ROSC
dosing.orderSentence: Targeted Temperature Management (TTM) — cooling to 32-36C 32-36C external/IV

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Active hemorrhage (relative); refractory cardiogenic shock (relative); terminal illness (relative)
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Core temperature (esophageal or bladder probe) continuously; shivering assessment (BSAS) q1h; electrolytes (K, Mg, Ca, Phos) q4-6h during cooling; coagulation q12h; skin checks q4h for surface cooling

Acute/Emergent.indication: Shivering during TTM (counterproductive; increases metabolic demand and defeats cooling); first-line anti-shivering agent

dosing.instructions: 25-50 mg IV q4h PRN shivering; first-line anti-shivering agent

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: MAOIs; seizure disorder (lowers threshold); renal impairment (normeperidine accumulation)

Acute/Emergent.indication: Adjunctive anti-shivering during TTM; lowers shivering threshold by 0.7C

dosing.instructions: 30 mg PO/NG q8h; lowers shivering threshold by 0.7C

Acute/Emergent.indication: Adjunctive anti-shivering; lowers shivering threshold and seizure threshold

dosing.instructions: 2-4 g IV bolus then 1-2 g/h infusion; target Mg 3-4 mg/dL

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Mg level q4-6h; deep tendon reflexes; HR

Acute/Emergent.indication: Refractory shivering despite first-line measures during TTM; note: obscures clinical exam and must be discontinued well before prognostication

dosing.instructions: 0.15 mg/kg IV bolus, then 1-3 mcg/kg/min infusion; titrate to train-of-four 1-2/4

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Train-of-four (TOF) q4h; cEEG mandatory when paralyzed (seizures undetectable clinically)

Acute/Emergent.indication: Post-arrest myocardial dysfunction with MAP <65 mmHg; first-line vasopressor for post-arrest shock

dosing.instructions: Start 0.05-0.1 mcg/kg/min; titrate to MAP >65 (or >80 if signs of cerebral hypoperfusion); max 2 mcg/kg/min

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Arterial line BP; MAP; urine output; lactate q4-6h

Acute/Emergent.indication: Post-arrest cardiogenic shock with reduced EF (<30%); augment cardiac output when vasopressors alone insufficient

dosing.instructions: Start 2.5 mcg/kg/min; titrate to cardiac output and MAP; consider with echo guidance

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: HR; BP; cardiac output (echo or PA catheter); arrhythmia

Acute/Emergent.indication: Adjunctive vasopressor for refractory hypotension when norepinephrine dose >0.3 mcg/kg/min

dosing.instructions: 0.01-0.04 units/min; does not titrate above 0.04

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: MAP; urine output; peripheral perfusion; serum Na

Acute/Emergent.indication: First-line for post-anoxic seizures and NCSE (common in 10-30% of comatose post-arrest patients); treat all electrographic seizures aggressively

dosing.instructions: 1000-1500 mg IV load; then 500-1000 mg IV BID; transition to PO when able; no hepatic metabolism; minimal drug interactions

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Severe renal impairment (dose adjust for CrCl <30)

Acute/Emergent.indication: Second-line for post-anoxic seizures; add if seizures refractory to levetiracetam

dosing.instructions: 20-40 mg/kg IV load over 15 min (max 3000 mg); then 500 mg IV q12h; target level 50-100 ug/mL

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Hepatic failure; mitochondrial disease (Alpers); pregnancy (teratogenic); thrombocytopenia
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: LFTs; ammonia; CBC; drug level; pancreatitis symptoms

Acute/Emergent.indication: Hyperglycemia (>180 mg/dL); target 140-180 mg/dL; avoid hypoglycemia (<70 mg/dL) which worsens neurologic injury

dosing.instructions: Continuous insulin infusion titrated to BG 140-180; transition to sliding scale when hemodynamically stable and tolerating nutrition

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: BG q1h while on drip; q4-6h on sliding scale; potassium with each BG

Acute/Emergent.indication: ALL intubated post-arrest patients; target normoxia and normocapnia

dosing.instructions: Target PaO2 75-100 mmHg (avoid hyperoxia PaO2 >300); PaCO2 35-45 mmHg (avoid hypo/hypercapnia); PEEP as needed

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: ABG q4-6h during active TTM; SpO2 continuous; EtCO2 continuous

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Sedation during TTM; additional anti-seizure properties; preferred for shorter-acting effect facilitating neurological assessment

dosing.instructions: 5-50 mcg/kg/min; titrate to RASS -4 to -5 during active TTM; wean after rewarming

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Propofol infusion syndrome risk (monitor for metabolic acidosis, rhabdomyolysis, hypertriglyceridemia if >48h at high doses >70 mcg/kg/min); egg/soy allergy
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Triglycerides q24h; CK if prolonged use; RASS; cEEG

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Analgesia and sedation during TTM; preferred analgesic during hypothermia (hepatic metabolism reduced)

dosing.instructions: 25-100 mcg/h continuous infusion; titrate to RASS target; bolus 25-50 mcg PRN

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Respiratory depression (ventilated patients); severe hepatic impairment
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: RASS; respiratory rate (if not ventilated); bowel function

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Alternative/adjunctive sedation if propofol contraindicated; anti-seizure properties

dosing.instructions: 0.02-0.1 mg/kg/h continuous; accumulates with prolonged use; prolongs sedation washout (confounder for prognostication)

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment; prolonged use delays prognostication
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: RASS; cEEG; watch for prolonged effect delaying prognostication

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Fever prevention and treatment post-TTM; target normothermia (<37.7C) for at least 72h post-ROSC

dosing.instructions: 1000 mg IV q6h scheduled (not PRN); max 4g/day

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: GI stress ulcer prophylaxis; post-arrest patients at high risk

dosing.instructions: 40 mg IV daily; transition to PO when tolerating

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: C. difficile risk with prolonged use

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: DVT prophylaxis; immobilized comatose patients at high VTE risk; start after active hemorrhage excluded and hemostasis adequate

dosing.instructions: 40 mg SC daily; start 24-48h post-ROSC if no active bleeding

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Platelet count; signs of bleeding; anti-Xa level if renal impairment

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: DVT prophylaxis; start IMMEDIATELY in all post-arrest patients

doseOptions.orderSentence: Pneumatic compression devices apply bilaterally external

dosing.instructions: Apply bilaterally on admission; maintain continuously when not ambulating
dosing.orderSentence: Pneumatic compression devices apply bilaterally external

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Post-anoxic myoclonus (both early status myoclonus and Lance-Adams syndrome); first-line for myoclonus suppression

dosing.instructions: Start 0.5 mg PO BID; titrate by 0.5 mg q3d to effect; max 6 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Severe respiratory depression (non-ventilated); severe hepatic impairment

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Post-anoxic myoclonus (adjunctive or alternative to clonazepam)

dosing.instructions: Start 250 mg PO BID; titrate to 500-1000 mg TID; target level 50-100 ug/mL

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Post-anoxic myoclonus (adjunctive; less effective as monotherapy for myoclonus than clonazepam)

dosing.instructions: Start 500 mg PO BID; titrate to 1000-1500 mg BID

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Post-anoxic refractory seizures not controlled by levetiracetam and valproic acid

dosing.instructions: 200 mg IV load over 15 min; then 100-200 mg IV BID; target level 10-20 ug/mL

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: PR prolongation >200 ms; second/third-degree heart block; severe hepatic impairment

dosing.instructions: 15-20 mg/kg IV load at 50-75 mg/min; then 1-3 mg/kg/day maintenance; target level 20-40 ug/mL

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Severe respiratory depression (intubated patients only); acute intermittent porphyria
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Drug level; respiratory status; BP (causes hypotension); sedation

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Continuous seizure activity despite two ASMs (refractory status epilepticus protocol)

dosing.instructions: 0.2 mg/kg IV bolus, then start 0.1 mg/kg/h; titrate q15min by 0.1 mg/kg/h to EEG seizure suppression or burst-suppression; max 2 mg/kg/h

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Super-refractory post-anoxic status epilepticus (when midazolam/propofol infusions fail)

dosing.instructions: 5 mg/kg IV load over 1h (may repeat 5 mg/kg boluses); maintenance 1-5 mg/kg/h; titrate to burst-suppression on cEEG

Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: cEEG; arterial line; vasopressors (nearly always required); ileus; temperature (poikilothermia)

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Adjunctive for refractory post-anoxic seizures; NMDA antagonism addresses late-stage glutamate excitotoxicity

dosing.instructions: 1-2 mg/kg IV bolus; then 1-5 mg/kg/h infusion; titrate to cEEG

Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: cEEG; BP (may increase); HR; oral secretions

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Elevated ICP with clinical signs of herniation (post-anoxic cerebral edema); acute temporizing measure

dosing.instructions: 1-1.5 g/kg IV bolus for acute herniation; 0.25-0.5 g/kg q4-6h maintenance

Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Serum osmolality q4-6h; Cr; urine output

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Acute herniation from post-anoxic cerebral edema; requires central venous access

dosing.instructions: 30 mL IV via central line over 10-20 min for acute herniation

Second-line/Refractory.indication: ICP management; less emergent than 23.4%; can give via peripheral line

dosing.instructions: 150-500 mL bolus or 0.5-1 mL/kg/h continuous infusion; target Na 145-155

Chronic/Rehabilitation Therapies (Surviv.indication: Secondary prevention of sudden cardiac death in survivors with cardiac etiology and EF <=35% (or per electrophysiology study); typically implanted before discharge or at 40 days post-MI

dosing.instructions: Per cardiology/electrophysiology; ICD vs S-ICD per anatomy

Chronic/Rehabilitation Therapies (Surviv.pretreatment: Cardiac workup complete; EF assessment; electrophysiology study if indicated; shared decision-making
Chronic/Rehabilitation Therapies (Surviv.contraindications: Active infection; terminal illness with <1yr life expectancy
Chronic/Rehabilitation Therapies (Surviv.monitoring: Device checks q3-6 months; wound; inappropriate shocks

Chronic/Rehabilitation Therapies (Surviv.indication: Arousal promotion in patients with disorders of consciousness (vegetative state/minimally conscious state); accelerates functional recovery

dosing.instructions: 100 mg PO BID (via NG if needed); increase to 200 mg BID; give before noon to avoid insomnia

Chronic/Rehabilitation Therapies (Surviv.pretreatment: Baseline renal function; seizure history assessment
Chronic/Rehabilitation Therapies (Surviv.contraindications: Renal impairment (dose adjust); seizure history (relative — lowers threshold)
Chronic/Rehabilitation Therapies (Surviv.monitoring: Renal function; seizure activity; livedo reticularis; hallucinations

Chronic/Rehabilitation Therapies (Surviv.indication: Depression and emotional lability in ABI survivors; common post-anoxic complication

dosing.instructions: Start 25 mg PO daily; increase by 25 mg q1-2 weeks; max 200 mg daily

Chronic/Rehabilitation Therapies (Surviv.pretreatment: Baseline ECG if cardiac risk factors
Chronic/Rehabilitation Therapies (Surviv.monitoring: Suicidality; serotonin syndrome signs; QTc if risk factors

Chronic/Rehabilitation Therapies (Surviv.indication: Cognitive impairment and attention deficits in ABI survivors; post-anoxic apathy/abulia

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg PO BID (morning and noon); titrate by 5 mg q3-5 days; max 60 mg/day; avoid afternoon dosing

Chronic/Rehabilitation Therapies (Surviv.pretreatment: Baseline HR and BP; cardiac arrhythmia screen
Chronic/Rehabilitation Therapies (Surviv.contraindications: Uncontrolled hypertension; severe anxiety; cardiac arrhythmia; psychosis
Chronic/Rehabilitation Therapies (Surviv.monitoring: HR; BP; appetite; sleep; behavioral changes

Chronic/Rehabilitation Therapies (Surviv.indication: Excessive daytime somnolence and fatigue in ABI survivors

dosing.instructions: Start 100 mg PO daily in morning; increase to 200 mg; max 400 mg/day

Chronic/Rehabilitation Therapies (Surviv.indication: Spasticity in ABI survivors with upper motor neuron signs; post-anoxic posturing or hypertonia

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg PO TID; titrate by 5 mg/dose q3d; max 80 mg/day; do not stop abruptly
Start 2 mg PO TID; titrate by 2 mg q3-7d; max 36 mg/day

Chronic/Rehabilitation Therapies (Surviv.pretreatment: Baseline LFTs; avoid concurrent CYP1A2 inhibitors
Chronic/Rehabilitation Therapies (Surviv.contraindications: Hepatic impairment; concurrent CYP1A2 inhibitors (fluvoxamine, ciprofloxacin)

Chronic/Rehabilitation Therapies (Surviv.indication: Focal spasticity in ABI survivors (upper or lower extremity) not responding to oral agents

doseOptions.orderSentence: Botulinum toxin type A (Botox) per muscle group IM

dosing.instructions: Dose per target muscles; typical total 200-400 units; repeat q12 weeks; onset 3-7 days
dosing.orderSentence: Botulinum toxin type A (Botox) per muscle group IM

Chronic/Rehabilitation Therapies (Surviv.pretreatment: Muscle selection by trained provider; identify target muscles with ultrasound/EMG guidance
Chronic/Rehabilitation Therapies (Surviv.contraindications: Infection at injection site; neuromuscular junction disorder
Chronic/Rehabilitation Therapies (Surviv.monitoring: Weakness (focal); dysphagia (if cervical muscles); antibody formation

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology/neurocritical care consult for neuroprognostication guidance and seizure management in all comatose post-arrest patients
Cardiology consult for coronary evaluation, post-arrest myocardial dysfunction management, and arrhythmia workup
Electrophysiology consult for ICD evaluation in cardiac arrest survivors with arrhythmic etiology
Palliative care consult for goals of care discussion and family support when neuroprognostication suggests poor outcome
Physical therapy for early mobilization protocol when neurologically and hemodynamically stable; passive range of motion to prevent contractures in comatose patients
Occupational therapy for ADL assessment, cognitive rehabilitation, and adaptive equipment in ABI survivors
Speech-language pathology for swallow evaluation (high aspiration risk in ABI survivors), communication assessment, and cognitive-linguistic rehabilitation
Neuropsychology for formal cognitive assessment in ABI survivors at 3-6 months post-injury to identify specific deficits and guide rehabilitation
Rehabilitation medicine (physiatry) for comprehensive rehabilitation planning and disposition (acute rehab vs skilled nursing)
Social work for family support, advance directive assistance, guardianship if needed, and community resource coordination
Chaplain/spiritual care for spiritual support for patient family during critical illness and end-of-life discussions
Organ procurement organization (OPO) notification when brain death or withdrawal of life-sustaining treatment being discussed; federal requirement in most jurisdictions
Psychiatry consult for post-cardiac arrest anxiety, PTSD, depression in survivors who regain consciousness

Patient / Family Instructions.item: Explain that anoxic brain injury occurs because the brain was deprived of oxygen during cardiac arrest and that recovery is unpredictable in the first 72 hours

Reassure family that targeted temperature management (cooling) is a standard evidence-based treatment and that the patient appears deeply sedated because of medications and cooling, not necessarily because of brain injury severity
Explain that formal neuroprognostication will not occur until at least 72 hours after rewarming because sedation and hypothermia confound the neurological exam
Inform family that neuroprognostication uses multiple tests together (exam, EEG, SSEP, MRI, blood tests) and that no single test alone determines outcome

If poor prognosis confirmed through multimodal testing, discuss goals of care including comfort care, withdrawal of life-sustaining treatment, and organ donation in a compassionate and unhurried manner
For survivors: explain that recovery from anoxic brain injury is a prolonged process (months to years); cognitive, emotional, and physical deficits are common; and rehabilitation is essential

For survivors: report immediately if new seizures (shaking, staring, confusion), worsening weakness, difficulty swallowing, or significant mood changes occur as these may indicate complications requiring treatment adjustment
For survivors: do not drive until formally cleared by neurology due to risk of seizures and cognitive impairment following anoxic brain injury
Provide written information about cardiac arrest survivors support groups and brain injury advocacy organizations (Brain Injury Association of America, Sudden Cardiac Arrest Foundation)

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Cardiac rehabilitation program enrollment for all cardiac arrest survivors to improve cardiovascular fitness and reduce recurrence risk
Smoking cessation as smoking increases cardiac arrhythmia and recurrent arrest risk
Strict medication adherence for cardiac medications (antiarrhythmics, beta-blockers, antiplatelets, statins) to prevent recurrent arrest
Alcohol cessation or strict limitation to reduce cardiomyopathy progression and seizure threshold lowering
Regular aerobic exercise (30 min moderate intensity 5 days/week) after cardiac rehabilitation clearance to improve cardiovascular outcomes
Mediterranean or DASH diet for cardiovascular risk reduction
Blood pressure target <130/80 mmHg for cardiovascular risk reduction
HbA1c target <7.0% for diabetic patients to reduce cardiovascular risk
CPAP compliance if obstructive sleep apnea present as OSA increases arrhythmia and recurrent arrest risk
Home AED (automated external defibrillator) placement for household members trained in BLS if patient at ongoing arrhythmia risk
Fall prevention program for ABI survivors with gait instability, cognitive impairment, or seizure risk
Cognitive rehabilitation exercises (memory aids, structured routines, environmental modifications) for daily function optimization

differential.features: History of prolonged sedation; improves with time after washout; normal SSEP and MRI
differential.tests: Sedation washout (5 half-lives); pharmacokinetic assessment; drug levels

differential.features: May mimic or coexist with anoxic coma; electrographic seizure activity; some patients improve with ASM treatment
differential.tests: cEEG (mandatory; seizures in 10-30% of comatose post-arrest patients)

differential.features: Renal failure, hepatic failure, electrolyte disturbances, hypothyroidism; potentially reversible
differential.tests: CMP; ammonia; TSH; renal function; blood gas

differential.features: History of trauma preceding arrest; focal findings on CT; epidural/subdural hematoma
Focal deficits; hemorrhage on CT preceding arrest; headache history
Focal deficits; vessel occlusion on CTA; asymmetric DWI changes
differential.tests: CTA; MRI DWI (focal rather than global restriction)

differential.features: Locked-in syndrome mimics coma; preserved vertical eye movements and blinks; posterior circulation stroke
differential.tests: CTA (basilar occlusion); MRI brainstem DWI; clinical exam for locked-in

differential.features: Drug overdose, poisoning (CO, cyanide); may respond to specific antidotes; history of exposure
differential.tests: Toxicology screen; carboxyhemoglobin; cyanide level; osmolar gap

differential.features: Environmental exposure history; core temp <35C preceding arrest; reversibility with rewarming
differential.tests: Core temperature; history; rewarm before declaring poor prognosis

differential.features: Inconsistent exam findings; may resist eye opening; normal EEG, SSEP, MRI
differential.tests: EEG (normal alpha); SSEP normal; MRI normal; caloric testing (nystagmus)

differential.diagnosis: Brain death / death by neurologic criteria
differential.features: Absent all brainstem reflexes; no respiratory drive; irreversible cessation of all brain function
differential.tests: Formal brain death evaluation protocol (see separate template)

evidence.recommendation: TTM at 32-36C for at least 24h in comatose cardiac arrest survivors
evidence.source: [TTM2 Trial Investigators. NEJM 2021](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/34133859/) — hypothermia at 33C vs normothermia (37.5C): no significant difference in mortality or neurological outcome at 6 months; [Bernard et al. NEJM 2002](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11856794/) — initial trial showing benefit of 33C; [HACA Trial. NEJM 2002](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11856793/)

evidence.recommendation: Avoid fever (target <37.7C) for at least 72h post-ROSC
Multimodal neuroprognostication no earlier than 72h after rewarming
evidence.source: [Sandroni et al. Intensive Care Med 2014](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25223853/); ERC/ESICM 2021 Guidelines; [AAN Practice Parameter Update 2023](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/36697245/)

evidence.recommendation: Bilateral absence of N20 on SSEP predicts poor outcome (FPR <1%)
evidence.source: [Sandroni et al. Intensive Care Med 2014](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25223853/); [Zandbergen et al. Neurology 2006](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/16924008/) — PROPAC study; [Bouwes et al. Neurology 2012](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22853736/)

evidence.recommendation: NSE >33 ug/L at 48-72h predicts poor outcome
evidence.source: [Stammet et al. JACC 2015](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25975474/) — TTM biomarker substudy; [Sandroni et al. Intensive Care Med 2014](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25223853/)

evidence.recommendation: Highly malignant EEG patterns (suppression, burst-suppression without reactivity) predict poor outcome
evidence.source: [Westhall et al. Neurology 2016](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26865516/) — TTM EEG substudy; ERC/ESICM 2021; [Hofmeijer et al. Clin Neurophysiol 2015](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26070341/)

evidence.recommendation: Absent pupillary reflexes at >=72h after rewarming predicts poor outcome
evidence.source: ERC/ESICM 2021; [Sandroni et al. Intensive Care Med 2014](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25223853/); Automated pupillometry (NPi) more reliable than manual assessment

evidence.recommendation: Extensive DWI restriction on MRI at 2-7 days predicts poor outcome
evidence.source: [Wijman et al. Neurology 2009](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/19577962/); [Mlynash et al. Neurocrit Care 2010](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20595666/)

evidence.recommendation: CT gray-white ratio <1.10 at 24-48h predicts poor outcome
evidence.source: [Metter et al. Resuscitation 2011](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/21592642/); [Lee et al. Resuscitation 2016](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/27746243/)

evidence.recommendation: Emergent coronary angiography for STEMI post-arrest
evidence.source: AHA 2020 Guidelines; [Lemkes et al. NEJM 2019 (COACT trial)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/30883050/) — immediate vs delayed angiography in non-STEMI shockable arrest: no difference
[Kilgannon et al. JAMA 2010](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20516417/) — hyperoxia associated with increased mortality; [Roberts et al. JAMA 2018](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/30458483/)
AHA 2020 Guidelines; [NICE-SUGAR Trial. NEJM 2009](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/19318384/) — intensive glucose control increases mortality in ICU

evidence.recommendation: Post-anoxic status myoclonus within 72h associated with poor outcome but not invariably fatal
evidence.source: [Elmer et al. JAMA Neurology 2016](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/30686160/); [Seder et al. Crit Care Med 2015](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26274731/) — some patients with early myoclonus survive with good outcome

evidence.recommendation: Lance-Adams syndrome (chronic post-hypoxic myoclonus in awake patients) compatible with good neurological outcome
evidence.source: [Lance and Adams. Brain 1963](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/13928399/); [Freund et al. Medicine 2017](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/29520368/)

evidence.recommendation: Amantadine accelerates recovery in disorders of consciousness
evidence.source: [Giacino et al. NEJM 2012](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22375973/) — primarily TBI patients; extrapolated to ABI

evidence.recommendation: Self-fulfilling prophecy avoidance: early WLST biases outcome data
evidence.source: [Geocadin et al. Circulation 2019](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31291775/) — AHA scientific statement; [Steinberg et al. Neurology 2020](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/32024674/)

[Ruijter et al. JAMA Neurology 2022 (TELSTAR trial)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/35695374/) — aggressive vs standard treatment of electrographic status epilepticus: no difference in primary outcome; treat clinical and electrographic seizures

evidence.recommendation: cEEG monitoring recommended for all comatose post-arrest patients
Avoid early withdrawal of life-sustaining treatment (<72h post-rewarming)
evidence.source: [Sandroni et al. Intensive Care Med 2020](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/32519006/); ERC/ESICM 2021

monitoring.frequency: Continuous during TTM; q4h after rewarming
monitoring.action: Adjust cooling device; anti-shivering protocol; investigate fever source

monitoring.frequency: q1h x 24h during TTM; q2h x 24h after rewarming; q4h thereafter; formal exam at >=72h after rewarming
monitoring.action: If declining: STAT CT; rule out new event; reassess prognostication

monitoring.frequency: Continuous x 48-72h minimum; longer if seizures detected
monitoring.action: Treat seizures aggressively; highly malignant pattern (suppression, burst-suppression without reactivity) is poor prognostic sign

monitoring.frequency: q1h during insulin drip; q4-6h on sliding scale
q4-6h during TTM (hypothermia causes intracellular K shift, hypomagnesemia); q12h after rewarming
monitoring.action: Aggressive replacement; arrhythmia risk if uncorrected

monitoring.frequency: At 24h, 48h, 72h post-ROSC; check for hemolysis (invalidates result)
monitoring.action: Interpret as part of multimodal prognostication; >60 ug/L highly predictive of poor outcome

monitoring.item: Pupillary light reflex (including automated pupillometry if available)
monitoring.frequency: q1h during acute phase; formal assessment at >=72h after rewarming
monitoring.action: Absent at >=72h after rewarming is poor prognostic sign; automated pupillometry more quantitative; reduce confounder effect
Adjust osmotherapy; free water restriction vs replacement

disposition.criteria: ALL comatose cardiac arrest survivors require ICU admission for: TTM, cEEG, hemodynamic monitoring, mechanical ventilation, neuroprognostication at >=72h after rewarming
Ongoing TTM or rewarming phase; hemodynamic instability requiring vasopressors; active seizures; mechanical ventilation; pending formal neuroprognostication

Completed TTM and rewarming; hemodynamically stable off vasopressors; no active seizures; extubated with adequate airway; neuroprognostication suggests potential recovery; awaiting rehabilitation placement
Following commands consistently; medically stable; can tolerate 3 hours/day of therapy; motivated for rehabilitation; functional deficits amenable to rehabilitation interventions
Unable to tolerate 3h/day of rehabilitation therapy; chronic disorders of consciousness (vegetative or minimally conscious state) requiring ongoing medical management; tracheostomy/PEG care
Requires prolonged ventilator weaning; ongoing complex medical needs; not yet stable enough for SNF or rehabilitation
Alert, communicating; ambulatory or safe with home support; seizures controlled; cardiac workup complete; medications reconciled; follow-up arranged; home AED placed if indicated

disposition.disposition: Comfort care / withdrawal of life-sustaining treatment
disposition.criteria: Multimodal neuroprognostication at >=72h post-rewarming confirms poor outcome by at least 2 independent modalities (exam, EEG, SSEP, MRI, NSE); family informed and goals of care aligned; palliative care involved
Clinical suspicion of brain death (absent brainstem reflexes, no respiratory drive); proceed with formal brain death protocol (see Brain Death Evaluation template)
When brain death confirmed or withdrawal of life-sustaining treatment planned; OPO notified per federal requirement; family approached by OPO designated requestor
